newsitem.title: BRAZIL: BRAZIL SHRS SEEN OFF ON U.S. RATES, EYES ON B BAND.
newsitem.headline: BRAZIL SHRS SEEN OFF ON U.S. RATES, EYES ON B BAND.

text.p: Brazilian stocks are likely to open lower on concern about U.S. interest rates amid volatile trade and speculation ahead of futures and options expiry, brokers said.
"The market was feeling pressured yesterday and that will continue today," said a dealer at local Cresiful brokerage.
The Sao Paulo bolsa's Bovespa index of 47 most-traded shares ended down 1.59 percent at 12,322 points on moderate trade of 800.96 million reais ($738.2 million).

Brokers said prices at the open could follow Thursday's trend, weighed down by higher interest rates in the United States amid volatile trade as speculation mounts ahead of August 13 futures settlements and August 18 options expiry.
Stocks could react positively if large premiums were offered for two B band cellular concession areas, they said.

The Communications Ministry began opening bid envelopes for area No. 2 covering non-metropolitan Sao Paulo state and area No. 10 comprising six northeastern states at 0900 local/1200 GMT. "People will be watching the B Band auction," one local trader said.

One analysts said telecom stocks, including benchmark Telebras and its state-level operating units, could be hit again by profiot-taking on fears that the B Band license winners will offer competitive cellphone rates.
"Aggressive tariff proposals could mean further profit-taking for the telecoms," he wrote in a report.
